full_threads.body:
Hi David, 


Yes you can add a shop tab on your Facebook page. Here is an article on it: https://ecommerce-platforms.com/ecommerce-selling-advice/how-to-create-a-facebook-shop-page 


But yes, you can simply do a post as well. In some ways this will get more cut through as it pushes the content to the user versus them having to hunt around for it. You could also do a boosted post, it may be a good lead generation tool. I.e. You may interest a parent that first buys the poster and then signs up their child down the track.


Hope that helps,

Hi Heath,


All details look great on the web page, I like how it all comes together. Do you have any advice, guidance on how to utilise a Shop function on Facebook to direct users to the Store page? Or is it matter of just making post and linking to that page?


Regards, David
Fwd: A couple of things

Perfect, thanks Heath


Regards, David

Hi David, 


Sure please have a look now? Is that correct? 


Thanks,

Hi Heath,


All looks good. Can you just update the “Non-for profit” to “Not-for profit’” as below. In addition, can you alter the ‘Non-for-Profit’ menu header to ‘Not-for-profit’ (note, I have also put it in sentence case).


Regards, David

Hi David, 


Sure, all done - let me know what you think? 


Thanks and speak soon,
Fwd: A couple of things

Hi Heath,


Thank you for the update, all details and the test emails work fine. Let’s move it into production. Can you please include the menu item as “Store” and put it where the Pop-up library currently is on the far right (as this now sits under the “Non-for-Profit menu).


In addition, can you alter the ‘Non-for-Profit’ menu header to ‘Not-for-profit’ (note, I have also put it in sentence case).


…and finally, thank you for adding the 3 articles. For the article below (which was in regards to Ellaslist) could you please bring the third sentence (starting with “There is a prevalent lack……”) to a new paragraph. Can you also move the sentence towards the bottom “Think of it as strapping on a helmet before riding a bike…..” also to a new paragraph.


Regards, David

Hi David, 


The product page is good to go. I just did a test to demo a failed order and a successfull order. You can test yourself to see the entire process. The funds will also appear in Stripe. 


I have setup a coupon code called TESTER which brings total right down. 


We will need to add this to the top menu as well. Did you have a preference of where? 


Thanks and speak soon,

Hi Heath - I have been looking around at various shopping options and cost, let’s just go with the flag shipping of $10. Can you also highlight, shipping only Within Australia.


Let me know once things are up and working and ready to go. Are you able to test through the entire shopping process so that I can see what notifications/ email we get.

Regards, David
Great thanks David.

Thanks Heath, let me come back to you on this. I will aim to have a fixed cost for shipping which covers all of this (by State)


Regards, David

Hi David, 


Great to hear it's loading correctly for you now. Sorry about the postage, you did previously ask about this. There are 2 components, the packaging and postage. 


Packing:


I'm assuming a tub style of packaging would be best and have looked up some options for you:  

A3: $2.55 each - https://shop.auspost.com.au/product/mailing-tubes-tu1-60-x-420mm-90013m
A1: $5.35 each - https://shop.auspost.com.au/product/mailing-tubes-tu3-90-x-850mm-40898m  


The pricing comes down for bulk orders. 


Postage: 


I struggled to find any pricing online for actually sending these tubes... Generally it's a fixed price for within the same state and then another price for interstate. Once we know what these are we can structure the shipping costs by adding the packaging and postage fees and adding this to their cart total. 


The other option would be a drop shipping approach, whereby you work with an print-mail house. They could receive a copy of the order (items, quantity and address) and then print and deliver directly to the customer. It would be a more costly option potentially, but very convenient. I'm not sure if Fineline do this, but could be worth a phone call? 


The other option is to give the customer the option to pick it up (not sure where from, maybe Castle Hill HQ or one of the other locations). I say this because the shipping cost is going to close to the actual price of the product and may be a deterrent for purchasing. Once you have more products thought, the way to avoid this is bundle and charge reduced or no shipping based on a minimum dollar value spend. 


Let me know your thoughts on the above and if you want me to pop into the post office for pricing. 


Thanks and speak soon,

Thanks Heath, all looks good and works now. Final question (before going live), how does the postage work / calculate?


Regards, David

Hi David, 


I'm thinking it's a caching issue as we have checked it on all browsers and it's loading perfectly. We have reset the website cache, but can you please refresh your browser cache and try again. 


If it's still not loading correctly, please tell me which browser you are using. 


FYI, from the screen shot I can see a little magnifying glass icon on the right-hand side of the address bar. Please click this to reset your zoom as it can skew things also.

Thanks and speak soon,

Hi Heath,


This is how I see it on the computer, which seems to cut off the video (which means it is hard to press play).


Regards, David
Help Heath understand how they’re doing:

Thanks for the updates, confirming we have completed all of them, except for: 



  •  The bottom of the page and the ‘Teaching aids’ page have been cut off with the arc (as mentioned below) 


***Can you please send a screen shot of this, I can't see what you see, it's weird. 


Regarding the Promo code, this is on the cart and checkout pages.


Regarding the video request, we would need to swap the locations of the gallery and video. It's too cumbersome to have the video as part of the gallery if that makes sense. Please let me know your thoughts on this? I think for consistency, it's best to have the video where it is as I'm assuming we won't a video for all future products... But happy to take your direction on this one. 


Thanks and speak soon,

As used in Ready to Read lessons (see left), these sound charts demonstrate the sounds of the alphabet using engaging pictures.

Use this chart to:

  • Help your child learn phonics and develop their phonemic awareness
  • Demonstrate to your child that letters have both names and sounds

Regards, David

On 30 May 2018, at 4:24 pm, david@readytoread.com.au wrote:

Hi Heath,

In regards to the online shop, the first items that we are wanting to make available is our sound chart. Additional details and comments are as follows:

  • A3 Size sound chart: $11.95 + postage
  • A1 Size chart: $19.95 + postage
  • You have the image of the Sound chart which is ok to add. Can we also add the follow short video which shows the Sound chart in use, as well as one of our teachers going through each sounds (we will also use the video to promote and direct people where they can purchase the sound chart as well. It is also a good education video for parents too).
    • https://spark.adobe.com/video/uknADkZaEEcs3
    • The attached picture (depending on the quality) can also be utilized.
    • I can add the video on Vimeo as needed so you can upload. Let me know if this is what I should do?

The 2 items are the initial items that we want on the shop. We will also add a few other items over the coming month (including Flashcard, RTR Activity book and Sound chart placemat. As for the subscription model, that is still some time away, I wanted to flag it to you to make you away of some broader offerings as well.

Regards, David

From: david@readytoread.com.au <david@readytoread.com.au>
Sent: Tuesday, May 22, 2018 12:48 PM
To: 'Heath Maguire - Wolf IQ' <heath@wolfiq.com.au>
Cc: 'Michelle Mowbray' <michelle@readytoread.com.au>
Subject: RE: A couple of things

Hi Heath, please find below the responses to the question

1. We’d like to sell our sound charts online – A4, A3 and A1. We know our ‘back end’ has purchasing functionality due to our online enrolment, but just wondering what this would look like or what’s involved? Particularly if we’d need to look at adding or including postage? Just after your advice on this as we’d like to set it up properly and then add to our range of items being sold online in the future.

***Yes we can adapt the online enrolment functionality to work with a traditional online sale. The only difference is that it would be missing two elements being, a shopping cart and the ability to calculate shipping rates based on the purchasers address. If either of those features are required, we would install a more traditional e-commerce setup to handle that side of things. I can talk you through the pros and cons of each if you like. Ultimately the shopping cart will allow for a more balanced and rapid growth of the product line.

DM – ideally it would be good to have a shopping cart approach. Initially we are wanting to sell the posters, but we will be adding additional items (eg: flashcards, some books, place mat and a few other items). In addition, one additional thing we are looking to do is to offer an online subscription product (eg: 12 month subscription, for an introductory online program for parents). This offering would be a 12 month subscription, whereby children get access to 26 X short 10 min lessons as an additional/complementing offering via a medium outside of our classroom, which is also accessible in location s that RTR is not currently servicing (we will be coming to you do to discuss more when the time is right). I wanted to flag this to provide perspective when you are recommending what option for the online Shopping

*****Ok, I think based on the above the shopping cart approach is going to work best. This will take a bit of integration, so will be outside of your Perk Plan. It will take approx 4 hours. Please let me know if you would like us to proceed and we can schedule it in for this week. Please also provide the copy, pricing etc and we can use the Poster as the first product. We can create some sales images, but if you have any great photos of it in situ, they may come in handy too. When it comes time for the subscription model, we will need to add this on as a separate task as it has a few more variables from the automated billing side of things.
